questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with painless swelling in the umbilical region. On physical examination, the swelling is found to be soft, smooth, and freely mobile in a direction perpendicular to the line of the mesentery. Imaging studies confirm the presence of a mesenteric cyst. Which of the following is not a component of Tillaux's triad?

choices.text: Soft, smooth swelling in the umbilical region
Freely mobile in a direction perpendicular to mesentery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Presence of tenderness

Explanation:
Presence of tenderness is not a part of Tillaux’s triad.

Mesenteric cyst:

  • It presents as a painless, abdominal swelling in the umbilical region.
  • Commonly seen in the 2nd decade of life.
  • There is a band of resonance in front of the cyst.

Tillaux's triad for mesenteric cysts includes:

  • A soft, smooth swelling in the umbilical region. (Option A ruled out)
  • Freely mobile mass in a direction perpendicular to line of the mesentery (Tillaux Sign) (Option B ruled out)
  • A zone of resonance all around. (Option D ruled out)

Complications of mesenteric cysts:

  • Torsion of cyst can lead to volvulus of adjacent bowel.
  • Rupture of the cyst.
  • Hemorrhage into the cyst.
  • Infection

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with abdominal distension, colicky pain that worsens after meals, and a gradual decline in her overall health. On examination, she has multiple hernias and ascites that do not demonstrate shifting dullness. Imaging reveals a jelly-like substance throughout the peritoneal cavity and mesentery. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Ascitic fluid due to liver cirrhosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pseudomyxoma peritonei

 

Explanation:

Pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) is a rare condition characterized by the progressive accumulation of tumor deposits in the peritoneum, along with mucinous ascites and the formation of an omental cake. PMP is typically caused by the perforation of a mucinous appendiceal tumor.

 

Clinical Features of pseudomyxoma peritonei:

  • Many patients remain asymptomatic during the early stages.
  • Abdominal distension is common.
  • Colicky pain, particularly after eating, results from partial intestinal obstruction.
  • There is a progressive decline in overall health as amino acids are diverted for the production of the jelly-like substance.
  • On physical examination:
    • Multiple hernias may be observed due to increased intra-abdominal pressure.
    • Ascites is present but lack shifting dullness, owing to the accumulation of a semi-solid substance.

Investigation:

  • High-resolution CT scan of both the abdomen and pelvis, incorporating oral and intravenous contrast

Treatment:

  • Cytoreductive Surgery (CRS): This includes multiple peritonectomy procedures and may involve extensive multivisceral resections to achieve complete tumor removal (complete cytoreduction).
  • Hyperthermic Intraperitoneal Chemotherapy (HIPEC): Following CRS, HIPEC is administered to target any remaining microscopic disease. Common agents used are mitomycin C or oxaliplatin.

 

Ovarian Cystic Tumor (Option A): Although ovarian tumors can present with abdominal distension and discomfort, they are less likely to cause the jelly-like substance seen in the peritoneal cavity, which is more indicative of pseudomyxoma peritonei.

 

Ascitic Fluid due to Liver Cirrhosis (Option C): Ascites due to cirrhosis presents with free fluid in the abdomen that typically demonstrates shifting dullness on examination. The jelly-like appearance and lack of shifting dullness are inconsistent with simple ascitic fluid.

 

Colorectal Carcinoma (Option D): While colorectal cancer can lead to peritoneal carcinomatosis, it generally does not produce the jelly-like material described in this case, which is more specific to pseudomyxoma peritonei.

questions.text: A CT scan reveals periaortic soft tissue mass encasing both ureters. Regarding retroperitoneal fibrosis, which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Methysergide use is a recognized etiology in some cases.
Bilateral ureteric obstruction is best managed initially with bilateral nephrostomies.
Tamoxifen is contraindicated in the medical management of this condition.
Laparoscopic ureterolysis with omental wrapping is a surgical option for persistent cases.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tamoxifen is contraindicated in the medical management of this condition.

 

Explanation:

Tamoxifen is one of the medical management options for retroperitoneal fibrosis.

 

Clinical Presentation of Retroperitoneal Fibrosis:

  • Dull, non-colicky lower back or flank pain
  • Weight loss, fatigue, anorexia
  • Lower extremity edema (due to venous compression)
  • Scrotal swelling or varicocele (due to testicular vein compression)
  • Symptoms of renal failure if bilateral ureteral obstruction occurs

 

Diagnosis:

  • CT or MRI showing periaortic soft tissue mass
  • Elevated inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP)
  • IVP: medial deviation of the ureter known as medial pulling or pipestem ureter (due to inflammation causing fibrosis and contraction)

  • Biopsy may be required to exclude malignancy

Management:

  1. Medical management:
    • Corticosteroids (first-line treatment)
    • Immunosuppressants (e.g., azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil)
    • Tamoxifen (hormonal therapy)
  2. Surgical management:
    • Ureterolysis with omental wrapping
    • Laparoscopic or open approach

 

Methysergide use is a recognized etiology in some cases (Option A): Methysergide, an ergot alkaloid used for migraine prophylaxis, has been associated with causing retroperitoneal fibrosis.

 

Bilateral ureteric obstruction is best managed initially with bilateral nephrostomies (Option B): In cases of significant obstruction causing renal impairment, temporary urinary diversion with nephrostomies or ureteric stents is often the first step before definitive treatment.

 

Laparoscopic ureterolysis with omental wrapping is a surgical option for persistent cases (Option D): For cases that don't respond to medical management or have persistent ureteral obstruction, laparoscopic ureterolysis with omental wrapping is a recognized surgical approach.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of liver cirrhosis and ascites presents to the emergency department with fever, abdominal pain, and tenderness. Paracentesis is performed, and the ascitic fluid analysis shows an elevated white blood cell count. Which of the following organisms is the most common cause of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis in patients with ascites along with its source of infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Escherichia coli, Extraperitoneal source


Explanation:

  • Escherichia coli is the most common organism causing spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) in patients with liver cirrhosis and ascites.
  • SBP typically results from the translocation of enteric bacteria (extraperitoneal source) into the ascitic fluid. This process occurs due to the compromised gut barrier function and immune system in cirrhotic patients.

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is a type of Primary Bacterial Peritonitis where there is inflammation of the parietal and serosal layer of the peritoneum without any documented source of infection.

The most common causes of SBP are Escherichia coli (gram negative bacteria), Streptococci and Enterococci (gram positive cocci).

 

Type of Peritonitis

Microbial Characteristics

Primary

Monomicrobial, extraperitoneal source, blood spread

Secondary

Most common, polymicrobial, intra-peritoneal source

Tertiary

Due to superadded infection following treatment of secondary/primary

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding spontaneous bacterial peritonitis

choices.text: Translocation of bacteria from the gut causes SBP
Neutrophil count >250/mm is present in SBP
Cefotaxime is the first-line treatment for SBP
SBP is a polymicrobial infection of ascitic fluid

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) SBP is a polymicrobial infection of ascitic fluid

Explanation:

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is an acute bacterial infection of ascitic fluid. It often affects individuals with a history of cirrhosis and ascites. SBP is a monobacterial infection, usually translocated from the gut to the ascitic fluid. (Option A ruled out)

Clinical features:

  • Abdominal pain and tenderness
  • Fever with chills and rigor
  • Tachycardia

Investigations:

  • Paracentesis gives a definitive diagnosis.
  • A confirmed diagnosis requires an elevated neutrophil count of 250/mm3 or higher in the aspirated ascitic fluid (Option B ruled out)

Treatment:

  • Drug of choice: IV Cefotaxime + Albumin (Option C ruled out)
  • Patients with cirrhosis often experience hypoalbuminemia for which Albumin is administered.

questions.text: What is the most common anaerobe responsible for Secondary Bacterial Peritonitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bacteroides fragilis

Explanation:

Secondary bacterial peritonitis results from bacterial contamination originating from the digestive tract mainly seen secondary to visceral perforation.

Etiology:

  • Most common anaerobic pathogen: Bacteroides fragilis
  • Most common aerobic pathogen: E.coli (Option A ruled out)

Management:

  • Erect Chest X-ray: Useful for detecting free gas under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum), indicating a perforation
  • Surgery: Exploratory laparotomy + Peritoneal lavage + Repair of perforation

 

Klebsiella (Option C): Although Klebsiella is a common pathogen in other intra-abdominal infections, it is not the most common anaerobe in secondary bacterial peritonitis.

 

Clostridium difficile (Option D) is typically associated with antibiotic-induced colitis, not secondary bacterial peritonitis, and is not a major cause of peritoneal infection.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis are true?

choices.text: The most common organism causing peritonitis in CAPD is Staphylococcus saprophyticus
Treatment involves intraperitoneal instillation of first-generation cephalosporin via catheter for treating CAPD peritonitis
Recurrent attacks of peritonitis in CAPD should not be considered hemodialysis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Treatment involves intraperitoneal instillation of first-generation cephalosporin via catheter for treating CAPD peritonitis

 

Explanation:

Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) related peritonitis is a major cause of technique failure, morbidity, and mortality in patients with CAPD.

The most frequent cause of peritonitis in Continuous Ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis (CAPD) is also Staphylococcus epidermidis. (Option A ruled out)

 

Most common site of intraperitoneal abscess:

  • In recumbent or lying down position: Morrison pouch/subhepatic space
  • In upright posture: Pelvis (Pouch of Douglas)
  • MC site (Overall): Pelvis (Pouch of Douglas)

 

Treatment:

  • Administer first-generation cephalosporin intraperitoneally through the catheter.
  • For patients experiencing repeated episodes of peritonitis:
    • Replace the catheter.
    • Consider switching to hemodialysis. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of worsening lower abdominal pain, fever, and diarrhea with mucus. She reports a feeling of pressure in her pelvis and says that even sitting is excruciating. Her medical history is significant for diverticulitis, which was treated conservatively 6 weeks ago. Tenderness to palpation in the lower abdomen, and a rectal examination are present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pelvic Abscess

 

Explanation:

This patient's symptoms, combined with her recent history of diverticulitis, point towards a pelvic abscess.

 

Clinical Features of Pelvic Abscess:

  • Lower abdominal pain and tenderness due to pus accumulation.
  • Fever accompanied by chills and rigor.
  • Pus irritates the anterior rectal wall (since the pouch of Douglas is in contact with this area) causing multiple episodes of loose stools with mucus.
  • Digital rectal examination may reveal a bulge on the anterior wall of the rectum.

 

Investigation:

  • Initial investigation: Ultrasound.
  • Investigation of choice: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT).

 

Management:

  • If a clean window is present:
    • Percutaneous aspiration guided by ultrasound or CT (preferred treatment) is performed.
  • If no clean window is available due to bowel loops adhering to the abscess cavity:
    • For females: Posterior colpotomy through the posterior vaginal wall (in close contact with the pouch of Douglas).
    • For males: Anterior rectal drainage through the anterior rectal wall.

 

Acute Appendicitis (Option A) typically presents with periumbilical pain that migrates to the right lower quadrant (RLQ). Fever and nausea are common, but the presence of diarrhea with mucus and a pelvic pressure sensation make this diagnosis less likely, particularly given her history of diverticulitis.

 

Diverticulitis Flare-up (Option B): While diverticulitis can recur, the presence of pelvic pressure and excruciating pain upon sitting suggests progression to a more severe complication like an abscess, rather than a simple flare-up.

 

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (Option C) typically affects younger, sexually active women and presents with bilateral lower abdominal pain, fever, and vaginal discharge. The patient’s age and lack of sexual or gynecological history reduce the likelihood of PID in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true about mesenteric cyst?

choices.text: Enterogenous cyst has an independent vascular supply
Walls of chylolymphatic cysts are thicker than enterogenous cysts
Treatment of chylolymphatic cyst is resection and anastomosis
Fluid in enterogenous cyst is produced by goblet cells of viscera

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fluid in enterogenous cyst is produced by goblets cells of viscera

 

Explanation:

Chylolymphatic Cyst

Enterogenous Mesenteric Cyst
  • Cyst has chylous collection.
  • Congenitally misplaced lymphatics in the ileum with afferent lymphatics only.
  • Absence of efferent lymphatics → collection of chyle → progressive increase in the size of the cyst.
  • Independent vascular supply and there is no shared wall.
  • TOC: Enucleation.
  • “Entero” means: small bowel and “genous” means: Origin.
  • Indirectly or directly arising from the small bowel.
  • Patients have either diverticula or duplication cysts.
  • Over a period of time, the diverticula will be walled off leading to the formation of 2 separate lumens, known as duplication cyst.
  • The small intestine is lined with columnar epithelium and goblet cells which secrete mucin and collect inside the cyst increasing its size (enterogenous cyst).
  • Treatment: Resection + Anastomosis (due to shared wall and shared vascular supply).

questions.text: A male presents with bilateral flank pain, lower extremity edema, and elevated serum creatinine. CT scan reveals a retroperitoneal mass encasing both ureters. Biopsy shows dense fibrocollagenous tissue with chronic inflammation. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) IgG4-related disease

Explanation:

IgG4-related disease is currently recognized as the most common cause of idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (IRF).

  • This systemic condition is characterized by dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates rich in IgG4-positive plasma cells, storiform fibrosis, and often elevated serum IgG4 levels.
  • The CT findings of a retroperitoneal mass encasing the ureters, along with the biopsy showing dense fibro-collagenous tissue with chronic inflammation, are typical of IgG4-related retroperitoneal fibrosis.

 

Types of Retroperitoneal Fibrosis (RPF):

  1. Primary RPF (accounting for 70% of the cases, also known as Ormond’s disease)
  2. Secondary RPF

Causes of Secondary RPF

Chronic inflammation

Drugs

Malignancies

Others

Mnemonic: “CATH”

  • Chronic pancreatitis
  • Actinomycosis
  • TB
  • Histoplasmosis

Mnemonic: “MAHE BP”

  • M – Methysergide (Most important drug)
  • A – Amphetamines
  • H – Hydralazine
  • E – Entacapone
  • B – Beta-blockers,
  • Bromocriptine
  • P – Phenacetin
  • Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Carcinom stomach
  • Carcinoid tumor
  • Autoimmune disorders
  • Radiation exposure

Diagnosis:

  • IOC for diagnosis: CECT.
  • IVP: medial deviation of the ureter known as medial pulling or pipestem ureter (due to inflammation causing fibrosis and contraction)


 

Metastatic prostate cancer (Option B)

  • It can spread to the retroperitoneum and cause fibrosis. However, the biopsy would typically show malignant cells. Also, prostate cancer metastasis usually presents with bone pain.

Methysergide use (Option C):

  • Methysergide, an ergot alkaloid used in the treatment of migraines, was historically associated with retroperitoneal fibrosis. However, its use has been largely discontinued due to this side effect.

Erdheim-Chester disease (Option D):

  • Erdheim-Chester disease is a rare non-Langerhans cell histiocytosis that can cause retroperitoneal fibrosis. However, it typically presents with bone pain, diabetes insipidus, and characteristic radiographic findings in the long bones.
  • The biopsy in Erdheim-Chester disease would show foamy histiocytes.
